titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. October 1803. I left my father’s house at Quincy, where after quitting my own in Boston, I had pass’d a few days, and with my wife, her sister, and my two children, went to Providence. Mr: Otis the Secretary of the Senate went with us. Our intention was to embark at Providence for Powles Hoek—New-York being inaccessible by the prevalence of a malignant distemper— But being detained two days at Providence by the wind, Mr: Otis on the 3d: of October left us and proceeded in the Stage.
4. October 1803. Sailed from Providence in the Packet Cordelia and went down to Newport, where we were detained two days more by adverse winds
7. October 1803. Sailed from Newport, and beat against contrary winds all that day and night

8. October 1803. At 8 in the morning we were compelled to put in to the Harbour of New-London, where we remained the whole day— But in the evening the wind becoming favourable, we embarked again just before midnight

9. October 1803. After a pleasant run of 15 hours we landed at 3. this afternoon at Powles Hoek. We immediately took a carriage which brought us to Newark— Here, my wife was seized with a most violent fever; which occasioned a further unavoidable detention
12. October 1803. My wife beginning to recover was just able to ride as far as Elizabeth-Town.
14. October 1803. We commenced again our Journey and went to Princetown.
15 October 1803. Rode from Princetown to Frankford, within five miles of Philadelphia. We were obliged to avoid this City, for the same reason, as New-York.

16. October. 1803: Sunday— Remained at Frankford, principally on account of my wife, who had not yet fully recovered, and after two successive days of riding, required one of rest— My brother came out from Philadelphia to see us.

17. October 1803. This was the day on which Congress met, conformably to the President’s Proclamation— The various delays I experienced on the Journey, and particularly my wife’s illness, rendered it impossible for me to attend in time— I went this day from Frankford to Wilmington— Delaware.
18. Travelled from Wilmington in Delaware to Havre de Grace— Maryland.
19. Rode from Havre de Grace, to Baltimore.— At the place where we dined, I saw the President’s Message on opening the Session of Congress.

20. Came from Baltimore to the City of Washington— The Treaty for the cession of Louisiana, with the two Conventions connected with it, had this day the advice and consent of the Senate to their ratification. The yeas 24. Nays 7.—

21. October 1803.— I this day delivered my credentials to Mr: Otis the Secretary of the Senate: had the Oath to support the Constitution of the United States administered to me by Mr: Brown, the President pro Tempore, and took my seat.— The Senators all here, but Genl: Sumpter and Mr: John Smith

22. Mr: Clinton moved for a Resolution to amend the Constitution by altering the mode of electing the President and Vice-President of the United States, so that the electors shall designate the person, to fill each of those respective Offices— Mr: Clinton press’d for a decision upon the Resolution, this day, or at farthest on Monday next, because he was anxious to obtain the amendment in time to make it bear upon the next Presidential Election; and as the legislatures of Vermont and Tennessee are now in Session, if the opportunity should be lost of sending the resolution to them, they would not be able to act upon it in due season, without being called together expressly for the purpose— Mr: Tracy contended that the Resolution could not be finally acted upon in Senate, either this day or Monday— For it being a Resolution which required the concurrence of the House of Representatives, it must be read three times on different days like a bill— Such having been the rule heretofore adopted and declared by the Vice-President.— Mr: Clinton questioned the rule, and as a point of order it was referred to the decision of the President, who said he knew of no such rule; of course it was determined that the Resolution required but one reading— Notwithstanding this decision, there is such a rule, and its infraction at this time was only for the purpose of getting through Mr: Clinton’s Resolution by a coup-de-main— But when this obstacle was surmounted, others arose from Mr: Clinton’s own side of the House, which he found it impracticable to overcome— He had worded the Resolution with such precipitation, that it contained a manifest absurdity; a provision for a case which it was impossible should happen— This was first removed— By altering the mode of election in the case of the President, it made some alteration in that of the Vice-President, obviously proper— Under the present mode a plurality of votes only, is required for the Vice-President, and Mr Clinton’s Resolution, left that unaltered— An amendment was proposed by Mr: Bradley, making a majority of votes necessary for the Vice-President, under the proposed mode of election— After some discussion of this, Mr: Butler proposed another Amendment, declaring that no person shall be eligible as President, more than twice in succession, and that any person having been President, shall be eligible after an interval of four years, only for one more term of four years— By this time the subject had become so complicated, that a postponement of further consideration, was called for untill Monday, and denied, 16 to 15.— But after carrying this vote, the Resolution, which required the concurrence of two thirds of the House, could still not be carried through— The subject was therefore at last by a bare majority, referred to a Committee of five to report on Monday.

24. October 1803. The Committee appointed to consider and report upon the proposed Resolution of Mr: Clinton, and the amendments moved to it, made a report ready printed, adopting Mr: Bradley’s Amendment into the body of the Resolution, and Mr: Butler’s into a separate Resolution; when the subject was taken up for consideration, Mr: Dayton, moved to strike out all the part of the report that bore reference to the election of a Vice-President, with a view to abolish the Office itself, which in his view would become altogether useless under the alteration of the Constitution now contemplated— This motion opened a new and wide field for debate— The members of the majority being most of them pledged by opinions formerly express’d in favour of Mr: Dayton’s object, yet apprehensive that they would hazard the fate of their intended amendment by complicating it with other questions, were apparently disconcerted— To ward off Dayton’s amendment they were compelled to plead want of time to consider it, and yet to carry through Clinton’s Resolution, to resist every call for more time from the other side— The reason for this excessive hurry was repeatedly alledged to be the necessity of obtaining the adoption of Tennessee and Vermont, during the present Session of their legislatures— The true reason will appear hereafter— A question for postponement of the subject untill Wednesday was taken and lost— Upon which Mr: White of Delaware, declared that he could not be driven and forced on in such manner, and if the question must now be taken he should ask to be excused from voting on it, at-all— The majority would have been very glad to take him at his word, but still they could not carry their majority of two thirds, and were finally compelled to postpone the subject untill to-morrow. Mr: Clinton was so much vexed at the delay which he saw must be occasioned by Mr: Dayton’s proposition, that he quite lost his temper, and indulged himself in such personalities that Dayton declared he should take the proper notice of them elsewhere.

25. Tuesday. Mr: Clinton was recently appointed mayor, of the City of New-York, and being obliged to enter on the functions of that Office, at the commencement of the ensuing month, had made his arrangements for leaving this City, very early this morning, which he accordingly did— His friend Mr: Wright read in his place, a written apology, for the expressions he used yesterday, which gave offence to Mr: Dayton— After which Mr: Wright moved that the further consideration of the proposed amendment to the Constitution should be postponed untill to-morrow— Mr: Clinton, he said, had made his arrangements for quitting the City this morning, and had been anxious to get the resolution through, so that he might carry it home with him to his Constituents— This was the reason why the subject had been so much urged yesterday— But as Mr: Clinton was now gone, and several points of material importance were involved in the question, the further time which Gentlemen had appeared desirous to obtain, might be indulged.— Postponed accordingly.

Mr: Breckinridge some days since brought in a bill to enable the President to take possession of Louisiana, and to govern the Country, untill Congress shall further provide— It was debated this day at the second reading; and pass’d to the third.

Mr: Wright, on Saturday last laid on the table a Resolution, for coming to a new choice of Secretary, and other officers of the house— He called it up this day, but it was determined not to take up the consideration of it now, 16 and 15.
Mr: John Smith, a Senator from the State of Ohio, took his seat, and the oath to support the Constitution.

26. Wednesday. The bill for enabling the President to take possession of Louisiana, was debated at the third reading, and pass’d— Yeas 26— Nays 6.—of which my name was one— My objection was to the second Section, which appeared to me to contain unconstitutional provisions— And as we could not obtain either erasure or amendment of this Section, I voted against the bill.
27. October 1803. Thursday. A Treaty of limits with Great-Britain, signed on the 12th: of May last, by Mr: King, and Lord Hawkesbury, was read the second time; and referred to a Committee.—

Mr: Wright called up again his Resolution to come to a choice of a Secretary and other Officers— The grounds of the motion, alledged, are that there never has been a choice that of the first Congress under the Constitution— That the Senate, is no longer the same— That the House of Representatives choose their clerk at every new Congress, and that the Senate ought to do the same; or at least to choose once in six years— Mr: Jackson only spoke against the motion— He considered the Senate as a permanent body—differing therefore from the House of Representatives, and not under the same necessity of renewing the choice of their Clerk at every new Election— He thought it better to have our officers at all times under our own controul, and if any ground of complaint should appear against them at any time— He objected also upon the ground of the measure’s opening a door to perpetual teazing sollicitations for the Offices at every Session of Congress— And moved to postpone the further consideration of the subject untill the first Monday in October next.— The Virginia Senators, and Mr: Breckinridge replied, and appeared the most earnest for a change.— They said that to complain of the misconduct of the Officers, would be an invidious task, and lead to improper discussions— That it was much better to prepare the way for any necessary removal, by periodical elections— Mr: Taylor insisted that the Senate is not a permanent body; and quoted the Constitution, to prove that it is chosen for Six years— But the Constitution says no such thing— Mr: Jackson’s motion for postponement to a day beyond the Session, prevailed—17 to 13.

28. Friday.— Mr: Butler at the time when the Treaty for the cession of Louisiana was ratified, moved for a Resolution requesting the President to negotiate again with the French Government, to obtain a modification of the third Article— His object is to cede the territory west of the Mississippi to Spain in exchange for the Florida’s— This Resolution was debated very largely this day— Mr: Breckinridge, and the Virginia Senators oppose it as unconstitutional— The initial of all negotiations belonging exclusively to the President— And as inexpedient; the territory being too valuable to be given up— I concur in these opinions.— The question was not taken—

29. Saturday. The bill for enabling the President to take possession of Louisiana, came back from the House of Representatives, with two amendments introduced into the second Section— I proposed an Amendment to one of those Amendments, which however was rejected— So were the Amendments themselves; but the House insisted upon them. A Committee of Conference was appointed, who made report of a mezzo termine between the House and Senate; but in the mean time the House adjourned untill Monday— The Senate then became so impatient to complete the bill, that they rejected the report of the Committee of Conference, and adopted both the Amendments proposed by the House; so that the bill might be completed this day; which after all it cannot be.— As a rule of prudence, one house should not resist amendments from the other, unless it means to persevere eventually in that resistance— To begin by rejecting, and finish by adopting, is neither very considerate nor very dignified.

31. Monday. Mr: Breckinridge moved a Resolution that the Senate would wear crape one month, for the three illustrious patriots, Samuel Adams, Edmond Pendleton, and Stephens Thompson Mason— I called for the authority of the Senate to make such an injunction— Mr: Breckinridge referred to the manual, and acknowledged that it must be altogether optional for every member to comply with the Resolution or not— I then objected against it, as tending to improper discussions of character, and to produce unnecessary heats and animosities— The Resolution was finally severed into two— One for Mr: Mason, as for a member of the Senate— This pass’d unanimously, as a mere customary formality— The other after a long debate, pass’d by yeas and nays 21 and 10.
A Message from the President, with four Indian Treaties was read— The reading of the Treaties themselves was dispensed with, untill they shall be printed.

The Treaty of limits with Great-Britain was again taken up— Mr: Butler moved an Amendment in the 5th: Article, requiring that Commissioners should immediately be appointed, to run the line from the Lake of the Woods to the Mississippi— General Smith moved a postponement to consider whether the Article itself would not cut us off from claims acquired by the cession of Louisiana— It was accordingly postponed.
